And all said they feared coming forward over fears of retaliation, public shame and possible effects on their immigration status. â€œHaving to tell their husband and children of these despicable actions left them filled with shame and embarrassment,â€ Harris said. â€œSo throughout their dreadful experiences with Mr. Robinson, all four women remained silent.â€ He said as low-wage earners, they also all feared â€œmissing a payday, and not being able to afford rent or buy food for their families.â€ All four women withheld their legal names citing privacy concerns and are identified as Jane Does in court documents. They appeared at the news conference with their attorneys, but did not speak, and covered their faces with masks. The lawsuit also names Robinsonâ€™s wife Frances Robinson as a defendant, alleging that she enabled his behavior despite knowing about past sexual misconduct. It also blames her for the hostile work environment, saying she berated them with language that included ethnic slurs. One woman said she worked for the Robinsons from 2012 until 2024, and was assaulted at least 20 times in that span. Another said she worked for them from 2014 until 2020, and was assaulted at least 23 times. Another said she worked for them for a year before quitting in 2024 and was assaulted at least seven times. The fourth woman, who said she also acted as Frances Robinsonâ€™s personal assistant, hairdresser and cook, worked for them for 18 years before resigning in 2024. She cited similar experiences to the other women, but did not say how often she was assaulted. The women, some of whom worked for the Robinsons at the same time as each other, also kept stories of the assaults from one another, but are now bonding over their experience, the attorneys said. They declined to give details at the news conference about how they came forward and learned there were others. The suit seeks damages based on sexual battery, assault, false imprisonment, gender violence and other allegations. â€œObviously, no amount of money can compensate these women for what Mr. Robinson put them through,â€ Harris said. But he said the $50 million was warranted â€œbased on the gravity of Mr. Robinsonâ€™s despicable and reprehensible misconduct.â€ Plaintiffsâ€™ attorney Herbert Hayden said that while they felt the assaults are worthy of criminal investigation, the women have not filed police reports, based on the same fears that kept them from coming forward. Robinson, a member of both the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame and the Songwriters Hall of Fame, was among the biggest hitmakers of the 1960s â€” both with his group the Miracles and as a solo artist, with songs including â€œTears of a Clownâ€ and â€œThe Tracks of My Tears.â€ He was a central part of the Motown Records music machine in his hometown of Detroit as an artist, producer and songwriter for other artists.

headline: In pinstripes and hats, with canes and twists on suiting, Met Gala crowd largely did menswear proud
article_title: In pinstripes and hats, with canes and twists on suiting, Met Gala crowd largely did menswear proud
article_content: NEW YORK (AP) â€” Pinstripes. All Ways. Hats galore. Pantsuits. Gown suits. Zoot suits. Canes. A single cigar (looking at you Madonna) â€” and expert displays of tailoring. The Met Gala crowd, for the most part, did the Black dandy menswear theme proud at fashionâ€™s biggest party of the year. â€œThose that researched the moment and pulled inspiration from history made it modern and their own. I loved it,â€ said Holly Alford, assistant dean and an associate professor in the fashion and merchandising program at Virginia Commonwealth University School of the Arts. Among her favorites: Colman Domingoâ€™s homage to dandy icon AndrÃ© Leon Talley. It was one of many that honored the towering fashion figure, a rare Black fashion editor in a largely white industry. And among others in odes to Talley, who died in 2022, were Anne Hathaway in a Carolina Herrera dress she picked specifically for him. â€œWe wanted AndrÃ© Leon Talley to look down from heaven and scream â€˜GLAMOUR,â€™â€ Hathaway said on the Vogue livestream Monday night. A glamorous night it was, and an inventive one at that amid a broad White House siege on DEI programs and protections that serve immigrants, LGBTQ+ people and myriad others. What does that have to do with fashion and the theme this year? Everything, in terms of Black power, ownership, heritage and, most importantly, freedom. What, exactly, was the suggested dress code? It was â€œTailored for You,â€ inspired by Black dandyism through time, the subject of the Metropolitan Museum of Artâ€™s spring show at its Costume Institute. On the blue carpet, a bit soggy from drenching rain, guests played with the fundamentals of fashion to make their looks their own with the help of designers and stylists. And many honored their heritages in special touches like the cowrie shells on the cuffs of Lewis Hamiltonâ€™s Wales Bonner jacket. The shells pay homage to Black diasporic culture, to spirituality, to memory, said Rikki Byrd, assistant professor of visual culture studies at the University of Texas at Austin and founder of the Black Fashion Archive. Tessa Thompson honored Talley with a fan adorned with his image. â€œItâ€™s representative of a church fan and AndrÃ© Leon Talley often talked about his first introduction to fashion was through his church,â€ Byrd said. Teyana Taylor was a standout for Shantrelle P. Lewis, author of â€œDandy Lion: The Black Dandy and Street Style.â€ With her cane, in her red velvet cape, â€œshe understood the assignment,â€ Lewis said. Taylorâ€™s cape was emblazoned with her nickname in honor of her home turf: â€œHarlem Rose.â€ And she, like Swizz Beatz, donned a durag. Lewis, who has been seminal in understanding dandyism, said the attire on the carpet was generally underwhelming. â€œThe lack of color, the lack of African print, even the absence of African designers. I said, â€˜Where is the Black dandyism?â€™â€ she said. â€œNo sartorial risks were taken.â€ Big risks? Perhaps. Perhaps not. Brandon Tan, fashion director for Cosmopolitan, was satisfied. â€œA classic silhouette can be completely reimagined by something as simple as the color and fabrication of the textile, as seen on Henry Golding,â€ he said. â€œInversely, a very classic gray wool can be totally remixed by the cut and silhouette like Walton Gogginsâ€™ kilt look by Thom Browne.â€ A few simply showed up in comparatively routine black tuxedos (hello James Corden) and questionable spins on the theme (Sorry, Halle Berry, but that was a lot of skin in the crotch area). Coattails of varying lengths were a huge trend amid the sea of hats and head pieces anticipated ahead of the gala that brought together A-listers from the worlds of sports, entertainment, music, art, literature, politics and more to raise money for the Costume Institute. Black and white looks carried the night, with enough pops of color to keep it interesting. Kevin Huynh, InStyleâ€™s fashion director, also praised Domingo, who wore a huge Talley-esque collared blue cape first, then ditched the cape to reveal a pearled window-pane jacket he wore with dot accessories. â€œAs the undisputed king of the red carpet, his regal look was beyond appropriate for the nightâ€™s theme,â€ Huynh said. â€œHe fully embodied the spirit of dandyism in not one but two statement-making looks from Valentino, and he aced it in terms of being unapologetically bold and flawlessly fanciful.â€ That â€œfearlessness and individuality,â€ he said, is what the night was all about. â€œAfter a marathon awards season run, his Met Gala red carpet reveal was well worth the wait. From the moment he stepped out of The Carlyle draped in a jewel-toned Valentino cape, it was clear that more was coming,â€ said Claire Stern Milch, Elleâ€™s digital director. â€œAnd when he finally arrived on the steps, his custom three-piece zoot suit, also designed by Alessandro Michele, was a playful and sophisticated nod to the theme,â€ she added. Milch called Domingoâ€™s oversized polka dot flower on one lapel undoubtedly the highlight. The look, she said, was the â€œperfect marriage of classic tailoring and avant-garde flair.â€ Nikki Ogunnaike, editor-in-chief of Marie Claire, noted that suiting of all kinds wasnâ€™t a huge surprise, considering the style guidance from Vogueâ€™s Anna Wintour, who puts the gala together each year. â€œMy favorites included Ayo Edebiri in Ferragamo, Tracee Ellis Ross in Marc Jacobs, Zendaya and Lisa in Louis Vuitton, Colman Domingo in Valentino and Mindy Kaling in Harbison, all of whom interpreted dandyism and suiting in their own unique way,â€ she said. Athletes, meanwhile, also took the spotlight. Tailoring for them is a special craft that Tom Marchitelli, custom menswear designer and stylist, takes into consideration with all the suits he creates for NFL, NBA and Major League Baseball players. â€œThese guys have these superhero builds, as I like to say, and they canâ€™t walk into any store on Fifth Ave, in Rodeo, anywhere and just pick out a suit off the rack to fit them,â€ he said. Marchitelli said he appreciated the clean form-fitting looks on Philadelphia Eagles players Jalen Hurts and Saquon Barkley. â€œTo have this many athletes showcased, I think that says a lot about how important sport is to culture, pop culture in America, how influential the athletes are,â€ he said. The nightâ€™s vibe was inspired by the exhibit called â€œSuperfine: Tailoring Black Style.â€ Itâ€™s the first Costume Institute show to focus exclusively on Black designers, and the first in more than 20 years devoted to menswear. Big-time Black designers and smaller brands of creatives of color were represented on the carpet. They included Sergio Hudson, LaQuan Smith and Ozwald Boateng, a former wunderkind of Savile Row. So who are some others who blew it, or didnâ€™t even try to spin the theme? Blackpinkâ€™s Lisa might have walked the line in her look by Vuitton, a gala sponsor. She went pantless with little faces on black undies to go with her matching jacket and LV logo sheer stockings. Some on social media thought the faces were Rosa Parks. They werenâ€™t, a representative told The Cut, explaining they were â€œportraits of figures who have been a part of the artistâ€™s life.â€ OK. So it goes. Undie portraits might not be a good idea in general. As for Corden, The Cut posted a video of him in his mere mortal look and viewers threw some barbs, including one who called him â€œJames Boredonâ€ giving â€œa total snooze fest per usual.â€ Ouch, James. ___ For more coverage of the 2025 Met Gala, visit https://apnews.com/hub/met-gala.

headline: Man arrested after ramming car into front gate of Jennifer Anistonâ€™s Los Angeles home
article_title: Man arrested after ramming car into front gate of Jennifer Anistonâ€™s Los Angeles home
article_content: LOS ANGELES (AP) â€” A man was arrested after crashing a car into the front gate at Jennifer Anistonâ€™s home in Los Angeles, authorities said Tuesday. Police told KABC-TV that the â€œFriendsâ€ star was home at the time of the crash. The incident occurred around 12:20 p.m. Monday on the 900 Block of Airole Way in the wealthy Bel Air neighborhood, according to Officer Jeff Lee of the LA Police Department. Online property records show a home on that block owned by a trust run by Jennifer Anistonâ€™s business manager. Private security guards apprehended the driver and held him until police arrived. Lee described the suspect as a white middle-aged man. He has not been identified, and no charges had been filed as of Tuesday morning, Lee said. â€œHe used his vehicle to ram a gate to the residence,â€ Lee said. Messages were left Tuesday with representatives and attorneys for Aniston. Aniston, currently starring in Apple TVâ€™s â€œMorning Show,â€ purchased the midcentury mansion on a 3.4-acre lot for about $21 million in 2012, according to reporting by Architectural Digest.

headline: Things to know about the trial of Sean â€˜Diddyâ€™ Combs
article_title: Things to know about the trial of Sean â€˜Diddyâ€™ Combs
article_content: NEW YORK (AP) â€” The sex trafficking trial of Sean â€œDiddyâ€ Combs, one of the biggest music moguls and cultural figures of the past four decades, began Monday in New York with jury selection. Twelve jurors along with six alternates will be chosen, with opening statements expected to begin May 12. The trial is expected to last at least eight weeks. Hereâ€™s a look at some of the details. Combs is charged with one count of racketeering conspiracy, two counts of sex trafficking by force, fraud or coercion, and two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution. He has pleaded not guilty. The alleged offenses span from about 2004 until about 2024. Two of the counts were added a month before trial. The indictment against him says he coerced and abused women for years with help from a network of associates and employees while silencing victims through blackmail and violence, including kidnapping, arson and physical beatings. Prosecutors allege he used his â€œpower and prestigeâ€ as a music star to induce female victims into drugged-up, elaborately produced sexual performances with male sex workers in events dubbed â€œfreak offs.â€ Prosecutors revealed shortly before trial that Combs rejected a plea agreement that might have meant a lighter sentence than a conviction could. They did not disclose the terms of the proposed deal. Without identifying them publicly, prosecutors have said four of Combsâ€™ accusers will testify at the trial. The prosecution will be allowed to show the jury security video of Combs beating and kicking one of his accusers, the R&B singer Cassie, in a Los Angeles hotel hallway in 2016. Diddyâ€™s attorneys are expected to argue at trial that the government is demonizing and distorting the sexual activity of consenting adults. They have also argued that two of Combsâ€™ longtime girlfriends willingly brought a male sex worker into their relationship. Cassie, whose legal name is Cassandra Ventura, was Combsâ€™ on-again-off-again romantic partner for more than a decade. Her 2023 lawsuit against Combs alleging years of abuse, including rape, began the scrutiny that eventually led to his prosecution. The Associated Press does not typically name people who say they have been sexually abused unless they come forward publicly, as Ventura did. The trial is in the courtroom of U.S. District Judge Arun Subramanian. Heâ€™s a Columbia Law School graduate and former clerk for Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and was appointed a federal judge by President Joe Biden in 2022. The prosecution team consists of eight assistant U.S. attorneys, seven of them women. They include Maurene Ryan Comey, daughter of former FBI Director James Comey. She was among the prosecutors in the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, who was convicted of luring teenage girls to be sexually abused by Jeffrey Epstein. Combsâ€™ team of seven defense attorneys is led by New York lawyer Marc Agnifilo, who along with his wife Karen Friedman Agnifilo is also defending Luigi Mangione, the man accused of the murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson. Also on the defense team is Atlanta attorney Brian Steel, who represented Young Thug in a trial that went on for nearly two years before the rapper pleaded guilty to gang, drug and gun charges. Combs, 55, has been held at a federal jail in Brooklyn since his September arrest. His formerly jet-black hair is now almost completely gray because dye isnâ€™t allowed at the detention center. Combs, who had his own fashion line, has worn yellow jail uniforms in pretrial hearings. But for the trial, the judge said he can have up to five button-down shirts, five pairs of pants, five sweaters, five pairs of socks and two pairs of shoes without laces. Under federal court rules, no photos or video of the trial will be allowed. Courtroom sketches are permitted. Since 2023, dozens of women and men have been filing lawsuits against Combs claiming he sexually or physically abused them. Many of those people said they were slipped drugs at events hosted by Combs and were abused while they were incapacitated. Combs has denied all of the allegations through his lawyers. Some of those lawsuits have claimed that other celebrities were either present for or participated in the abuse. The great majority of those allegations, however, arenâ€™t part of the criminal case. Prosecutors have chosen to focus on a relatively small number of accusers and allegations where there is physical evidence or corroboration by witnesses.

headline: Summer Movie Guide 2025: Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s coming to theaters and streaming from May to August
article_title: Summer Movie Guide 2025: Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s coming to theaters and streaming from May to August
article_content: Ethan Huntâ€™s last mission? A new Superman? Happy Gilmore as a dad? Three genre-spanning Pedro Pascal movies, including a romance, a superhero movie and an A24 Ari Aster thriller? Hollywood is pulling out the stops this summer movie season, which kicks off with the release Marvelâ€™s â€œThunderbolts(asterisk)â€ on May 2. May also brings big studio releases like a live-action â€œLilo & Stitch,â€ â€œMission: Impossible 8" and a new Wes Anderson film. June heats up with race cars in â€œF1,â€ adventure in â€œHow to Train Your Dragon,â€ zombies in â€œ28 Years Laterâ€ and a New York love triangle with Dakota Johnsonâ€™s matchmaker in the middle in â€œMaterialists.â€ July is supercharged with â€œJurassic World Rebirth,â€ â€œSupermanâ€ and â€œFantastic Four: The First Steps.â€ And August closes out the season with comedies, big (â€œThe Naked Gunâ€) and dark (â€œThe Rosesâ€), horror (â€œWeaponsâ€) and a lighthearted body-swap (â€œFreakier Fridayâ€). Hereâ€™s The Associated Pressâ€™ guide to help make sense of the many, many options in theaters and at home. â€œAnother Simple Favorâ€ (Prime Video, streaming): Chill those martini glasses, Blake Lively and Anna Kendrick reunite with their â€œA Simple Favorâ€ director Paul Feig for this Italy-set sequel. â€œThunderboltsâ€ (Disney, theaters): Marvelâ€™s antiheroes Yelena Belova (Florence Pugh), Bucky Barnes (Sebastian Stan) and Red Guardian (David Harbour) kick off the summer movie season in superhero style. â€œItâ€™s a group of misfit toys that have been essentially thrown away at the beginning of the movie and have to figure out if they can work together to get themselves out of that mess,â€ director Jake Schreier told the AP. (Read APâ€™s review.) This image released by Marvel Studios shows, from left, Sebastian Stan, Hannah John-Kamen, Florence Pugh, Wyatt Russell and David Harbour in a scene from â€œThunderbolts.â€ (Disney-Marvel Studios via AP) â€œBonjour Tristesseâ€ (Greenwich Entertainment, theaters): ChloÃ« Sevigny and Claes Bang star in this new adaptation of FranÃ§oise Saganâ€™s lusty, stylish coming of age novel about a playboy father and his teenage daughter (Lily McInerny) on the French Riviera. â€œPavementsâ€ (Utopia, theaters): Alex Ross Perry takes an experimental approach to the traditional music biopic in his portrait of the indie rock group Pavement thatâ€™s better experienced than described. â€œRustâ€ (Falling Forward Films, theaters and VOD): The Alec Baldwin Western â€œRustâ€ is actually coming out after years in limbo and litigation. Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins was fatally shot on set in October 2021 and director Joel Souza was wounded during a rehearsal. Souza said at the filmâ€™s premiere at a festival in Poland in November that it was Hutchinsâ€™ husband, Matthew, who wanted the film to be finished. (Read APâ€™s review.) â€œThe Surferâ€ (Lionsgate, Roadside Attractions, theaters): Tensions are high on a â€œlocals-only beachâ€ when Nicolas Cage and his son return to try to catch some waves. (Read APâ€™s review.) â€œMagic Farmâ€ (MUBI, theaters): Amalia Ulman directs this absurdist comedy about a documentary crew who ends up in the wrong town, starring ChloÃ« Sevigny, Alex Wolff and Simon Rex. â€œWords of Warâ€ (Decal, theaters): Maxine Peake and Jason Isaacs star in this political thriller about journalist and human rights activist Anna Politkovskaya. Sean Penn produced. â€œVulcanizadoraâ€ (Oscilloscope, theaters): A black comedy following friends on a dark mission deep in the woods of Michigan. â€œFriendshipâ€ (A24, theaters): Paul Rudd and â€œI Think You Should Leaveâ€ comedian Tim Robinson star in this absurd, comedic film about male camaraderie. This image released by A24 shows Tim Robinson, left, and Paul Rudd in a scene from â€œFriendship.â€ (A24 via AP) â€œShadow Forceâ€ (Lionsgate, theaters): Kerry Washington and Omar Sy star in this Joe Carnahan-directed action thriller about a couple of ex-assassins running from their old boss (and trying to protect their young son). â€œNonnasâ€ (Netflix, streaming): Vince Vaughn stars in this Stephen Chbosky-movie based on a true story of a Brooklyn guy who hires Italian grandmothers to be the chefs at a restaurant after the loss of his own mother. Susan Sarandon, Lorraine Bracco, Talia Shire and Linda Cardellini also star. â€œFight or Flightâ€ (Vertical, theaters): Josh Hartnett, sporting bleached blonde hair, is a mercenary on a flight full of assassins in this bloody action-comedy at 30,000 feet. â€œCaught by the Tidesâ€ (Janus Films): Chinese filmmaker Jia Zhangke takes footage spanning 22 years to tell a story of love and longing that had Cannes critics raving last year. Zhao Tao stars. â€œJuliet & Romeoâ€ (Briarcliff Entertainment, theaters): Shakespeareâ€™s star-crossed lovers get the (pop) music treatment in this colorful take starring Clara Rugaard and Jamie Ward. â€œClown in a Cornfieldâ€ (RLJ Entertainment): This slasher from director Eli Craig (â€œTucker & Dale vs. Evilâ€) features a killer named Frendo. â€œLillyâ€ (Blue Harbor Entertainment, theaters): Patricia Clarkson plays equal pay activist Lilly Ledbetter in this biographical drama. This image released by Warner Bros. Pictures shows Brec Bassinger in a scene from â€œFinal Destination Bloodlines.â€ (Warner Bros. Pictures via AP) â€œFinal Destination: Bloodlinesâ€ (Warner Bros., theaters): Itâ€™s been 25 years since the â€œFinal Destinationâ€ franchise kicked off and theyâ€™re still finding new horrifying ways to kill off their characters. â€œHurry Up Tomorrowâ€ (Lionsgate, theaters): The Weeknd (Abel Tesfaye) plays a fictionalized version of himself in this psychological thriller about an insomniac musician from Trey Edward Shults, co-starring Jenna Ortega and Barry Keoghan. â€œLoveâ€ (Strand Releasing): This Norwegian film about two health care workers discussing relationship philosophies closes out Dag Johan Haugerudâ€™s â€œSex, Dreams, Loveâ€ trilogy. â€œSister Midnightâ€ (Magnet Releasing, theaters): This black comedy about an unhappy arranged marriage and a series of chaotic events was a Cannes selection in 2024. â€œThe Ruseâ€ (Seismic Releasing, theaters): This thriller centers on a caregiver and the mysterious patient sheâ€™s caring for in a remote home on the sea. â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ (Disney, theaters): This live-action reimagining of the 2002 classic about orphaned Hawaiian sisters who unknowingly adopt an alien was directed by â€œMarcel the Shell with Shoes Onâ€ filmmaker Dean Fleischer Camp. Sydney Agudong, who plays older sister Nani, said, â€œThe beauty of this movie is that it highlights the idea of Aloha and Ohana and the family dynamics that happen here along with the aliens and the Hawaiian roller coaster ride.â€ This image released by Disney shows the character Stitch, left, and Maia Kealoha, as Lilo, in a scene from â€œLilo &Stitch.â€ (Disney via AP) â€œMission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoningâ€ (Paramount, theaters): Nothing ever really ends in the land of franchise filmmaking, but the â€œfinalâ€ in the title suggests this could actually be Tom Cruiseâ€™s last ride as Ethan Hunt. Even if it isnâ€™t, audiences can trust itâ€™ll be full of death-defying spectacles worthy of the big screen. â€œFountain of Youthâ€ (Apple TV+, streaming): Natalie Portman and John Krasinski play siblings on a dangerous quest for the fountain of youth in this globe-trotting adventure from Guy Ritchie. â€œPee-Wee As Himselfâ€ (Max, streaming): This riveting two-part documentary about the life of Paul Reubens was crafted from some 40 hours of interviews and thousands of hours of archival footage. â€œJane Austen Wrecked My Lifeâ€ (Sony Pictures Classics, theaters): A Parisian bookseller gets invited to the Jane Austen writersâ€™ residency in this contemporary Austen-inspired romantic comedy written and directed by Laura Piani. â€œFear Street: Prom Queenâ€ (Netflix, streaming): Prom queen candidates begin to vanish in this latest â€œFear Streetâ€ installment, set in 1988. â€œThe Last Rodeoâ€ (Angel Studios, theaters): Neal McDonough plays a retired cowboy who decides to return to the ring in a bid to pay his sonâ€™s medical bills. This image released by Sony Pictures shows, from left, Ralph Macchio, Ben Wang and Jackie Chan in a scene from â€œKarate Kid: Legends.â€ (Jonathan Wenk/Sony Pictures via AP) â€œKarate Kid: Legendsâ€ (Sony Pictures, theaters): Jackie Chan and Ralph Macchio unite for the newest â€œKarate Kidâ€ film, set three years after â€œCobra Kaiâ€ and focusing on a new kid, Li, played by Ben Wang. â€œIt kind of harkens back to the previous entries in the franchise,â€ Wang said. â€œItâ€™s a kid who is a fish out of water who comes to a new city and has to face down bullies.â€ â€œBring Her Backâ€ (A24, theaters): â€œTalk to Meâ€ filmmakers Danny and Michael Philippou return with this creepy new movie about death, resurrection and the arrival of an adopted kid who is not quite right. Sally Hawkins plays the mother. â€œThe Phoenician Schemeâ€ (Focus Features, theaters): Benicio del Toro stars as one of the richest men in Europe, and father to nine sons and one daughter (Mia Threapleton), in Wes Andersonâ€™s newest film, featuring a typically starry ensemble including Tom Hanks, Michael Cera, Scarlett Johansson, Riz Ahmed and Benedict Cumberbatch. â€œThe Kingdomâ€ (Metrograph, theaters): This Cannes breakout is about a teenage girl who goes on the run with her estranged mob boss father one summer in Corsica. â€œGhost Trailâ€ (Music Box Films, theaters): Jonathan Millet directed this revenge thriller about a Syrian man in France who is in pursuit of the man who tortured him at an infamous military prison. â€œTornadoâ€ (IFC Films, theaters): KÅki, Jack Lowden, Takehiro Hira and Tim Roth star in this revenge thriller set in 1790s Britain. This image released by Lionsgate shows Ana de Armas in a scene from â€œBallerina.â€ (Murray Close/Lionsgate via AP) â€œBallerina,â€ (Lionsgate, theaters): Ana de Armas leads this â€œJohn Wickâ€ spinoff about a deadly (and classically trained) assassin. â€œThe Life of Chuckâ€ (Neon, theaters): This is not your typical Stephen King adaptation. Mike Flanagan directs the sentimental and supernatural story about the life of an ordinary man named Charles Krantz, told in three chapters. Tom Hiddleston, Mark Hamill, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Mia Sara, Benjamin Pajak and Karen Gillan are among the large ensemble cast. â€œThe Ritualâ€ (XYZ Films, theaters): Al Pacino and Dan Stevens as men of the church performing exorcisms? Sure, why not. â€œDangerous Animalsâ€ (IFC Films, theaters): Jai Courtney plays a serial killer who feeds his victims to sharks in this bonkers-sounding movie. â€œI Donâ€™t Understand Youâ€ (Vertical, theaters): Nick Kroll and Andrew Rannells are a couple vacationing in Italy in this dark comedy with an escalating body count. â€œStrawâ€ (Netflix, streaming): Taraji P. Henson leads this Tyler Perry drama about a single mother. â€œDan Da Dan: Evil Eyeâ€ (GKIDS, theaters): More adventures of Momo and Okarun in this series based on the popular manga by Yukinobu Tatsu. â€œDeep Coverâ€ (Prime Video, streaming): Bryce Dallas Howard plays an improv comedy teacher recruited by an undercover cop (Sean Bean) for a mission for which she enlists two of her students (Orlando Bloom and Nick Mohammed). This image released by Universal Pictures shows Mason Thames in a scene from â€œHow to Train Your Dragon.â€, (Universal Pictures via AP) â€œHow to Train Your Dragonâ€ (Universal, theaters): Unlike most live adaptations of animated movies, filmmaker Dean DeBlois is behind both. DeBlois said their goal was to make the film â€œreally immersive,â€ to dial up the sense of urgency and peril and â€œto just pull the audience in and make them feel like these dragons are real, that you could own one, you could fly on the back of one.â€ Mason Thames plays Hiccup and Nico Parker takes on the role of Astrid in this epic fantasy sure to enchant a new generation (and the one who grew up on the original). â€œMaterialistsâ€ (A24, theaters): Dakota Johnson plays a matchmaker torn between two prospects (played by Chris Evans and Pedro Pascal) in love story from â€œPast Livesâ€ filmmaker Celine Song. â€œItâ€™s a modern love story thatâ€™s set in New York City and itâ€™s inspired by the brief time that I worked as a professional matchmaker,â€ Song said. â€œI really tried in this film to be really honest about the marketplace of dating, as the people actually experience it and live it today.â€ â€œEcho Valleyâ€ (AppleTV+, streaming): Claire (Sydney Sweeney) shows up on her motherâ€™s (Julianne Moore) doorstep covered in someone elseâ€™s blood in this thriller from Brad Ingelsby. â€œThe Unholy Trinityâ€ (Roadside Attractions, theaters): Pierce Brosnan and Samuel L. Jackson lead this Western, set in 1870s Montana. â€œPrime Ministerâ€ (Magnolia, theaters): This documentary follows Jacinda Ardern through her tenure as prime minister of New Zealand. â€œSallyâ€ (NatGeo/Disney+, streaming): Blue Origin who? Sally Ride, the first American woman to go to space, is the focus of this new documentary that chronicles her professional accomplishments and her lesser-known personal life. â€œ28 Years Laterâ€ (Sony Pictures, theaters): The original team behind â€œ28 Days Later,â€ including director Danny Boyle and writer Alex Garland, return with a new entry featuring Aaron Taylor-Johnson, Jodie Comer and Ralph Fiennes. â€œElioâ€ (Disney/Pixar, theaters): This intergalactic adventure centers on an 11-year-old earthling (Yonas Kibreab) who is abducted by aliens and assumed to be a world leader. Oscar-winner Zoe SaldaÃ±a is part of the voice cast. Elio, voiced by Yonas Kibreab,in a scene from â€œElio.â€ (Disney/Pixar via AP) â€œMarlee Matlin: Not Alone Anymoreâ€ (Kino Lorber, theaters): Marlee Matlin gives an unflinchingly honest account of her experiences as a deaf actor in this funny and revelatory documentary, directed by Shoshannah Stern, who also is deaf. The film is closed captioned and includes verbal translations for hearing audiences. â€œSovereignâ€ (Briarcliff, theaters): Dennis Quaid, Nick Offerman and Jacob Tremblay lead this crime thriller about anti-government extremists and a police standoff. â€œ Bride Hardâ€ (Magenta Light Studios, theaters): Rebel Wilson is a secret agent whose skills come in handy at her friendâ€™s wedding when a hostage situation emerges in this Simon West-directed comedy. â€œEverythingâ€™s Going to Be Greatâ€ (Lionsgate, theaters): Bryan Cranston and Allison Janney are lifelong actors in regional theater trying to raise their very different sons. â€œAlma and the Wolfâ€ (Republic Pictures, theaters): Ethan Embry and â€œSinnersâ€ breakout Li Jun Li star in this psychological horror about a mysterious wolf attack and a police officerâ€™s missing son. â€œKPop Demon Huntersâ€ (Netflix, streaming): An animated action comedy about K-pop superstars who also hunt demons on the side. Damson Idris, left, and Brad Pitt in a scene from â€œF1.â€ (Warner Bros. Pictures via AP) â€œF1â€ (Warner Bros./Apple, theaters): Brad Pitt plays â€œthe best that never was,â€ F1 driver Sonny Hayes, whoâ€™s recruited to mentor a young up-and-comer (Damson Idris) in this high-octane film from â€œTop Gun: Maverickâ€ filmmaker Joseph Kosinski. Real racing cars were used, driver Lewis Hamilton consulted and a new camera system was developed to give audiences an immersive experience. â€œItâ€™s a story about a last-place team, a group of underdogs, and Sonny Hayes in his later years having one more chance to try to do something he was never able to do, which is win a race in F1,â€ Kosinski said. â€œM3GAN 2.0â€ (Universal, theaters): The creepy, dancing doll is back â€” as is an even more dangerous version on a killing spree whom she has to stop. Any questions? â€œM3gan 2.0.â€ (Geoffrey Short/Universal Pictures via AP) â€œSorry, Babyâ€ (A24, theaters): One of the big breakouts from this yearâ€™s Sundance Film Festival, the debut feature of writer-director-star Eva Victor follows Agnes, a grad student, in the aftermath of a sexual assault. â€œI wanted to make a film that was about feeling stuck when everyone around you keeps moving,â€ Victor said. â€œI really think the thing itâ€™s about is trying to heal and the slow pace at which healing comes and how itâ€™s really not linear and how there are joys to be found in the everyday and especially in very affirming friendships and sometimes, like, a sandwich depending on the day.â€ â€œHot Milkâ€ (IFC Films, theaters): Things heat up on the Spanish coast, where Sofia (Emma Mackey) and her mother (Fiona Shaw) have gone in hopes of helping her mysterious illness. There Sofia meets a beguiling stranger (Vicky Krieps). This Berlin selection is based on a novella by Deborah Levy. Scarlett Johansson nd Jonathan Bailey in a scene from " Jurassic World Rebirth.â€ (Jasin Boland/Universal Pictures and Amblin Entertainment via AP) â€œJurassic World Rebirthâ€ (Universal, theaters): Filmmaker Gareth Edwards (a â€œJurassic Parkâ€ superfan and the director of â€œThe Creatorâ€) is ushering in a new era of â€œJurassicâ€ movies and harkening back to the Steven Spielberg originals in this film with Scarlett Johansson, Mahershala Ali and Jonathan Bailey. Much about the film is being kept top secret, but Edwards said David Koeppâ€™s script read like a love letter to Spielbergâ€™s early work. â€œItâ€™s basically a mission story where these military types go to this island to get this DNA, then thereâ€™s a twist,â€ Edwards said. â€œThis family ends up involved and it becomes a story of survival. Itâ€™s like one giant roller coaster ride and once it gets going, it sort of doesnâ€™t stop.â€ â€œThe Old Guard 2â€ (Netflix, streaming): Charlize Theron is back with her immortal team for a new mission. KiKi Layne, Matthias Schoenaerts, Marwan Kenzari and Luca Marinelli also reprise their roles. â€œHeads of Stateâ€ (Prime Video, streaming): Heads of state get a glow up in this action comedy, in which Idris Elba plays the British prime minister and John Cena is the U.S. president who are forced to work together (along with Priyanka Chopra Jonasâ€™ MI6 agent) to defeat a foreign adversary. â€œ40 Acresâ€ (Magnolia, theaters): Danielle Deadwyler and Michael Greyeyes lead this post-apocalyptic thriller about a plague that has caused worldwide famine. This image released by Warner Bros.Pictures shows David Corenswet in a scene from â€œSuperman.â€ (Warner Bros. Pictures via AP) â€œBrickâ€ (Netflix, streaming): In this German horror, a couple wakes up to find theyâ€™re trapped in their apartment. â€œSupermanâ€ (Warner Bros., theaters): James Gunn is ushering in a new era of Superman, with a fresh face in David Corenswet and the promise that heâ€™s a different Superman than what audiences have seen before. Gunn told the AP that this is â€œa Superman thatâ€™s both more grounded in his own personality and his relationship, which is much more complex than has been in the past. And then also the big magic world of Superman being in the world of the DCU with flying dogs and robots and giant monsters.â€ Thereâ€™s romance with Rachel Brosnahanâ€™s Lois Lane, and a â€œpretty scaryâ€ Lex Luthor in Nicholas Hoult. â€œHeâ€™s actually going to kill (Superman),â€ Gunn said. â€œAnd thatâ€™s cool to see.â€ â€œDonâ€™t Letâ€™s Go to the Dogs Tonight â€ (Sony Pictures Classics, theaters): Actor Embeth Davidtz directs and stars in this critically acclaimed adaptation of Alexandra Fullerâ€™s bestselling memoir of growing up on a farm in the former Rhodesia before and after the 1980 election, as the colonial system crumbles. The story is told through the eyes of 8-year-old Bobo (Lexi Venter). â€œTyler Perryâ€™s Destination Weddingâ€ (Netflix, streaming): Madea goes to the Bahamas. This image released by Sony Pictures shows Jennifer Love Hewitt in a scene from â€œI Know What You Did Last Summer.â€ (Matt Kennedy/Sony Pictures via AP) â€œSkillhouseâ€ (Fathom, theaters): 50 Cent stars in this horror about influencers who are lured into a â€œcontent houseâ€ and forced to compete in deadly challenges. This image released by Paramount Animation shows Papa Smurf, voiced by John Goodman in the film â€œSmurfs.â€ (Paramount Animation via AP) â€œI Know What You Did Last Summerâ€ (Sony Pictures, theaters): Jennifer Love Hewitt and Freddie Prinze Jr. reprise their roles from the 1997 slasher in this new installment featuring an eerily similar situation and a cast of pretty young up-and-comers including Madelyn Cline, Chase Sui Wonders, Jonah Hauer-King and Tyriq Withers. â€œSmurfsâ€ (Paramount, theaters): Rihanna produced and stars as Smurfette in this new musical adventure. â€œThereâ€™s a purity to the Smurfs mythos,â€ said Nick Offerman, who voices Papa Smurfâ€™s brother Ken. â€œThat, I think, is what makes their appeal so timeless. Theyâ€™re a benevolent group of wee blue villagers who, you know, want to love one another and lead productive lives while fending off the worldâ€™s forces of evil, usually represented by the machinations of some wizards out for ill gotten gains.â€ â€œEddingtonâ€ (A24, theaters): Ari Aster re-teams with Joaquin Phoenix for this film about a standoff between a small-town sheriff and a mayor in the early months of the COVID-19 lockdowns. Pedro Pascal, Emma Stone and Austin Butler also star. This image release by 20th Century Studios/Marvel Studios shows Ebon Moss-Bachrach, as Ben Grimm/The Thing, left, and Joseph Quinn, as Johnny Storm/Human Torch, in a scene from â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Steps.â€ ( 20th Century Studios/Marvel Studios via AP) â€œUnicornsâ€ (Cohen Media Group, theaters): A young, single father from Essex (Ben Hardy) is disarmed when he falls for a drag queen. â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Stepsâ€ (Disney, theaters): Pedro Pascal, Vanessa Kirby, Joseph Quinn and Ebon Moss-Bachrach unite to play â€œMarvelâ€™s first familyâ€ in this retro-futuristic world set in 1960s New York. Director Matt Shakman (â€œWandaVision,â€ â€œItâ€™s Always Sunny in Philadelphiaâ€) said they are the only superheroes in their world and are the leading lights of their age. While the scale and world building were on another level, Shakman said, â€œitâ€™s also no different from all of the great comedies and dramas that Iâ€™ve done â€” in the end, it comes down to character, to relationships and to heart and humor.â€ â€œHappy Gilmore 2â€ (Netflix, streaming): Adam Sandler returns to the green (and one of his most beloved roles) after almost 30 years, along with Shooter McGavin (Christopher McDonald), Hal (Ben Stiller), Virginia (Julie Bowen) and Doug (Dennis Dugan) and an army of newcomers, including some Gilmore offspring. â€œThe first one is so iconic, we all kind of knew the world that we were stepping into,â€ said Conor Sherry, who plays one of his sons. â€œWe were like the newest additions to a long, long, long family.â€ â€œOh, Hi!â€ (Sony Pictures Classics, theaters): Molly Gordon and Logan Lerman lead this dark romantic comedy about a married coupleâ€™s first romantic weekend getaway. â€œDiciannoveâ€ (Oscilloscope, theaters): Luca Guadagnino produced this coming-of-age film about a 19-year-oldâ€™s journey of self-discovery. â€œTogetherâ€ (Neon, theaters): Real life couple Dave Franco and Alison Brie play a frighteningly codependent couple in this inventive body horror that had Sundance crowds raving. â€œThe Bad Guys 2.â€ (Universal Pictures/DreamWorks Animation via AP) â€œThe Bad Guys 2â€ (Universal, theaters): Sam Rockwell, Marc Maron, Craig Robinson, Awkwafina and Anthony Ramos return for another animated heist, but this time theyâ€™re teaming up with a new squad called the Bad Girls (voiced by Danielle Brooks, Maria Bakalova and Natasha Lyonne). â€œThe Naked Gunâ€ (Paramount, theaters): Liam Neeson flexes his particular set of comedy skills as Frank Drebin Jr. in this irreverent new entry from Lonely Island veteran Akiva Schaffer, featuring Paul Walter Hauser and Pamela Anderson. â€œSketchâ€ (Angel Studios, theaters): This horror comedy about a girlâ€™s drawings that come to life stars Tony Hale and Dâ€™Arcy Carden. â€œWeaponsâ€ (Warner Bros., theaters): Children are disappearing in filmmaker Zach Creggerâ€™s eerie follow-up to â€œBarbarian,â€ starring Josh Brolin, Julia Garner and Alden Ehrenreich. â€œFreakier Fridayâ€ (Disney, theaters): Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan are back as the body-swapping mother and daughter duo. â€œMy Motherâ€™s Weddingâ€ (Vertical, theaters): Kristin Scott Thomas directs and stars in this drama about a woman getting married for the third time, which is an occasion for her three daughters (Scarlett Johansson, Sienna Miller, Emily Beecham) to come home. â€œFixedâ€ (Netflix, streaming): An adult animated comedy from Genndy Tartakovsky about a dogâ€™s quest for one last adventure before being neutered. â€œNobody 2â€ (Universal Pictures, theaters): Bob Odenkirkâ€™s former assassin Hutch Mansell canâ€™t catch a break. This time, Keanu Reeves joins the bloody fun. â€œClikaâ€ (Sony Pictures, theaters): A small-town musician (Jay Dee) goes viral in this drama set in the world of Mexican American music. Itâ€™s the debut feature of Rancho Humilde CEO Jimmy Humildeâ€™s production company. â€œEast of Wallâ€ (Sony Pictures Classics, theaters): Kate Beecroftâ€™s debut film about a young horse trainer grappling with financial insecurity and grief in the South Dakota Badlands won the audience award in the NEXT section at the Sundance Film Festival. â€œEli Roth Presents: Jimmy and Stiggsâ€ (Iconic Events, theaters): A low budget â€œsplatter festâ€ for horror devotees, Joe Begos wrote, directed and stars. â€œWitchboardâ€ (Atlas, theaters): â€œStranger Thingsâ€™â€ Jamie Campbell Bower stars in this supernatural horror set in New Orleans (a remake of a 1986 cult classic). â€œLurkerâ€ (MUBI, theaters): Another Sundance gem, this paranoid thriller is the feature debut of â€œThe Bearâ€ and â€œBeefâ€ writer Alex Russell, about celebrity, fandom and being very online, featuring a buzzy young cast led by TheÌodore Pellerin and Archie Madekwe. â€œHONEY DONâ€™T!â€ (Focus Features, theaters): Margaret Qualley, Aubrey Plaza, Charlie Day, Billy Eichner and Chris Evans star in this dark comedy from Ethan Coen about a small-town private investigator and a string of mysterious deaths. â€œAmericanaâ€ (Lionsgate, theaters): This Sydney Sweeney-led crime thriller, a revisionist Western set in South Dakota, debuted at South by Southwest in 2023 and concerns the theft of a valuable artifact. â€œEdenâ€ (Vertical, theaters): Ron Howard directs Jude Law, Ana de Armas, Vanessa Kirby and Sydney Sweeney in this survival thriller set in the Galapagos after the first World War. â€œRelayâ€ (Bleecker Street, theaters): Riz Ahmed plays a corporate fixer in this contemporary riff on the paranoid thriller from â€œHell or High Waterâ€ filmmaker David Mackenzie. â€œGrand Prix of Europeâ€ (Viva Pictures, theaters): â€œF1â€ for the preschool set? This animated film is also set in the world of car racing. â€œThe Thursday Murder Clubâ€ (Netflix, streaming): Helen Mirren, Pierce Brosnan, Ben Kingsley and Celia Imrie play retirees who spend their time solving cold cases in this adaptation of Richard Osmanâ€™s bestseller, directed by Chris Columbus. â€œCaught Stealingâ€ (Sony Pictures, theaters): Filmmaker Darren Aronofskyâ€™s film is written by and based on the Charlie Huston books about an ex-baseball player (Austin Butler) who gets tangled up in New Yorkâ€™s criminal underworld in the 1990s. ZoÃ« Kravitz, Regina King, Liev Schreiber, Matt Smith and Bad Bunny also star. â€œThe Rosesâ€ (Searchlight Pictures, theaters): The modern reimagining of â€œThe War of the Rosesâ€ stars Olivia Colman and Benedict Cumberbatch as the feuding couple. It was written by Tony McNamara, the Oscar-nominated screenwriter of â€œPoor Thingsâ€ and creator of â€œThe Great,â€ and directed by Jay Roach. â€œThe Toxic Avengerâ€ (Cineverse and Iconic Events Releasing, theaters): Peter Dinklage stars as the titular superhero in this supremely gory and graphic film, which sat on the shelf for a few years in search of a distributor. Elijah Wood, Jacob Tremblay, Kevin Bacon and Taylour Paige also star. ___ This story has been corrected to report that Sally Ride was the first American woman in space, not the first woman in space. ___ For more coverage of this summerâ€™s upcoming films, visit: https://apnews.com/hub/movies

headline: James Gunn predicts summer of â€˜Supermanâ€™ to the rescue of the box office
article_title: James Gunn predicts summer of â€˜Supermanâ€™ to the rescue of the box office
article_content: LAS VEGAS (AP) â€” The 2025 box office has been hit with a deficit. Can the James Gunn-dubbed â€œsummer of â€˜Supermanâ€™â€ save it? Warner Bros. showed off a diverse and starry slate of its upcoming films on Tuesday, but the night was carried on the shoulders of Clark Kent. â€œI really do believe in this movie. And I do believe that there is a lack of human kindness, or at least a degradation of human kindness,â€ Gunn said. â€œThis is a movie that celebrates kindness and human love.â€ At the annual CinemaCon convention and trade show in Las Vegas, Gunn â€” the director and writer of the first film in the new iteration of the connected DC Universe â€” brought out its stars, who gushed over their experience making the film. â€œItâ€™s a great honor to play a role that exists so clearly in the public consciousness, to the point where everyone I think, even if you havenâ€™t seen a film or read a comic, you sort of know what the Superman symbol means and you know what it stands for,â€ said David Corenswet, adding that he hopes to â€œilluminate something new about the character, or even just bring the beloved character to a new audience.â€ Corenswet was joined onstage by Rachel Brosnahan, who plays Lois Lane, and Nicholas Hoult, who plays Lex Luthor. â€œJames makes a family out of every set,â€ Brosnahan said. â€œThe set is full of people who want to be there, who love making these movies. And itâ€™s such a joy to come to work every day. As many of you have probably heard from other people, itâ€™s not always like that.â€ Gunn was announced as the filmâ€™s director in 2023, shortly after he and Peter Safran became co-chairs and co-CEOs of DC Studios. â€œWe appreciate and share your passion for this art form,â€ Safran told a room full of theater owners. â€œItâ€™s the fulcrum of our ambitious DC Studios slate and itâ€™s what inspired James to shoot all over the world and push filmmaking technology to its limits, to propel moviegoers out of their homes into your theaters.â€ The film will be released theatrically in July amid a summer of superhero titles, including â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Stepsâ€ and â€œThunderbolts.â€ In addition to â€œSuperman,â€ Warner Bros. teased some of its April releases on the conventionâ€™s main stage, like Ryan Cooglerâ€™s â€œSinnersâ€ and â€œA Minecraft Movie,â€ but they also looked further down the road for 2025. In a nod to cinephiles, the studio kicked off its presentation by bringing out the stars of Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œOne Battle After Another,â€ including Leonardo DiCaprio and Regina Hall. The film is set to hit theaters in September. â€œIâ€™ve been wanting to work with Paul for over, gosh, almost 20 years now. Heâ€™s one of the most unique talents of our time,â€ DiCaprio said. â€œWith this film, heâ€™s tapped into something politically and culturally that is brewing beneath our psyche. But at the same time, itâ€™s an incredibly epic movie and has such scope and scale.â€ Director Joseph Kosinski and producer Jerry Bruckheimer also treated the audience to an extended sneak peak of â€œF1,â€ Brad Pittâ€™s Formula One racing drama premiering in June. In addition to Hollywood studios and stars boasting the theatrical menus they believe will lure audiences to cinemas, the annual convention is also a time to discuss current industry debates, like how long movies should stay in theaters and the extent to which studios should get into production with streaming companies. ___ This story has been updated to correct the spelling of Lex Luthor.

headline: Summer Movies: 11 breakout actors to watch
article_title: Summer Movies: 11 breakout actors to watch
article_content: Many of the big movies this summer might come from familiar places â€” whether theyâ€™re franchises, sequels or hybrid adaptations of beloved animated classics. But look closer and there are quite a few fresh faces making a splash with memorable characters new and old. The Associated Press spoke to 10 of the actors about the roles. Maia Kealoha was 6 years old when she saw an advertisement for an open casting call for the new hybrid â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ movie and promptly told her parents thatâ€™s what she wanted to do. Now 8, Kealoha, who was born on Hawaiiâ€™s Big Island, is making her film debut as the spirited Lilo in Disneyâ€™s new live-action adaptation, hitting theaters on May 23. â€œIt was so amazing,â€ Kealoha said. â€œI was really proud of myself.â€ Sydney Elizebeth Agudong, who plays Liloâ€™s older sister and caregiver Nani, praised her young co-star. â€œIt was amazing building a world with her,â€ Agudong, 24, said. â€œItâ€™s a lot of CGI and weâ€™re working with aliens and such and she was full of imagination and creativity.â€ Sydney Agudong, as Nani, in a scene from â€œLilo & Stitch.â€ (Disney via AP) Hailing from Kauaâ€™i, Agudong also came to the role from an open casting call. Being part of the film has been a special experience as a lifelong fan of the animated version and a proud Hawaii resident. â€œHawaiiâ€™s very much like tough love and soft heart,â€ Agudong said. â€œWe truly created a family and hopefully people can see that.â€ Happy Gilmore is a dad in the sequel coming to Netflix on July 25. The Gilmore boys, played by Ethan Cutkosky (â€œShamelessâ€), Conor Sherry (â€œShake Shackâ€), Maxwell Jacob Friedman (a pro wrestler) and newcomer Philip Schneider, â€œare just goons,â€ Schneider said. All came to the project strangers, though intimately familiar with a film theyâ€™d all grown up with. And everyone but Friedman, 29, had to prove they had a little skill on the ice. â€œI looked like a goon so they just assumed Iâ€™d be fine on the rink,â€ Friedman laughed. This image released by Netflix shows, background from left, Philip Schneider as Bobby, Maxwell Friedman as Gordie, Ethan Cutkosky as Wayne, Conor Sherry as Terry and John Daly as John Daly in â€œHappy Gilmore 2.â€ (Scott Yamano/Netflix via AP) The four actors quickly found their rhythm together on set in Jersey City playing the rambunctious, troublemaking Gilmore spawn during the four-month shoot. â€œThe fast pace of stupidity that we got to and what made us family was such an amazing thing,â€ Cutkosky, 25, said. â€œItâ€™s really hard to come by.â€ Friedman added: â€œIn between scenes, we could like look at each other and know what we were thinking and make each other laugh without talking.â€ Schneider, 24, attributed the atmosphere to their on-screen dad Adam Sandler, who made the whole set feel like a family. His genius, Schneider said, â€œis that he gets people he wants to work with and just sees what happens. He trusts the chemistry.â€ For Sherry, it was helpful so early in his career to get to see how Sandler could be both a giant in the industry and so humble. â€œThatâ€™s the dream, right? To balance both,â€ Sherry, 24, said. This image released by A24 shows Eva Victor in a scene from â€œSorry, Baby.â€ (Mia Cioffy Henry/A24 via AP) One of the breakout films from Sundance was â€œSorry, Baby,â€ a poignant drama thatâ€™s both funny and shattering about the aftermath of a traumatic event. Itâ€™s the feature debut of triple threat Eva Victor, who wrote, directed and stars as Agnes, a graduate student at a New England school. â€œI wanted to make a film that was about feeling stuck when everyone around you keeps moving that really didnâ€™t center any violence,â€ said Victor, 31, who uses they/she pronouns. Victor, who had a recurring role on â€œBillions,â€ was making short comedy videos online and writing for the satirical website Reductress when Oscar-winning â€œMoonlightâ€ filmmaker Barry Jenkins messaged them and asked if they had any scripts. Now, that script is going to be in theaters on June 27, through A24. â€œI hope the film finds people when they need it,â€ Victor said. This image released by Sony Pictures shows Ben Wang in a scene from â€œKarate Kid: Legends.â€ (Jonathan Wenk/Sony Pictures via AP) Ben Wang didnâ€™t know he was up against some 10,000 people vying to play the new Karate Kid. The 25-year-old actor, best known for his role on the Disney+ series â€œAmerican Born Chinese,â€ learned that after the fact. But it was a stressful month of not sleeping very well while waiting to hear if he got it, he said. â€œKarate Kid: Legendsâ€ (out May 30) brings together Jackie Chanâ€™s Mr. Han and Ralph Macchioâ€™s Daniel LaRusso for this new entry, about a teenager at a new school, Wangâ€™s Li, who has to learn from both. â€œItâ€™s a fun one to play,â€ Wang said. â€œAnd I get to try to kick Jackie Chan, which is new and exciting for me.â€ Nico Parker grew up with both the â€œHow to Train Your Dragonâ€ books and movies, so it was a dream come true when she got the chance to play Astrid in the new live-action adaptation (June 13). Mason Thames, left, and Nico Parker in a scene from â€œHow to Train Your Dragon.â€, (Universal Pictures via AP) â€œItâ€™s a difficult thing when thereâ€™s already such a brilliant version of Astrid out there,â€ Parker, 20, said. â€œThe main thing that I really wanted to be prevalent in everything was how driven she is and how it doesnâ€™t come easy. It takes effort and skill and determination.â€ Parker, the daughter of actor Thandiwe Newton and director Ol Parker, has been on sets her whole life. She was only 11 when she filmed Tim Burtonâ€™s â€œDumbo.â€ But this feels different, she said, because she really understands the scale and scope of being in a major franchise. â€œTo be older I feel as if Iâ€™m acknowledging way more what it means and doesnâ€™t mean,â€ she said. â€œAnd I get much more stressed about it.â€ This image released by Neon shows Benjamin Pajak in a scene from â€œThe Life of Chuck.â€ (Neon via AP) You canâ€™t blame filmmaker Mike Flanagan for assuming Benjamin Pajak was a skilled dancer. Pajak made his Broadway debut as Winthrop in â€œThe Music Manâ€ with Hugh Jackman and Sutton Foster. But ask Pajak, now 14, and he demurs that dancing is not exactly his strong suit. But you would never guess that to see him waltzing and sambaing across the floor (thanks to Mandy Mooreâ€™s choreography) in â€œThe Life of Chuckâ€ (out June 6). â€œFilm is so different from theater,â€ Pajak said. â€œBut there were just so many people kind of lifting me up and helping me throughout the process.â€ One of those was Mark Hamill, who plays his grandfather. Perhaps even more exciting than being in the movies? Sharing scenes with Luke Skywalker. Krypto the dog, in a scene from â€œSuperman.â€ (Warner Bros. Pictures via AP) Supermanâ€™s very good boy Krypto might be a computer-generated creation, but the inspiration was a very real dog: filmmaker James Gunnâ€™s rescue Ozu. It was difficult transition to life in a home â€” Ozu destroyed shoes, furniture and even his laptop. Gunn, who was at work writing â€œSuperman,â€ thought, â€œHow difficult would it be if Ozu had superpowers?â€ That was how Krypto came to be part of the newest â€œSupermanâ€ (out July 11), changing the story and the script. The white pup features prominently in the filmâ€™s trailer. At the Puppy Bowl earlier this year, Gunn said that Krypto is lovable and mischievous and has all the powers of Superman â€” yes, he can fly too. ___ For more coverage of this summerâ€™s upcoming films, visit https://apnews.com/hub/movies.

headline: Movie Review: â€˜Thunderboltsâ€™ is Marvel, and Florence Pugh, in high gear
article_title: Movie Review: â€˜Thunderboltsâ€™ is Marvel, and Florence Pugh, in high gear
article_content: As they so often do in Marvel Land, worlds collide in â€œThunderbolts.â€ But in this refreshingly earthbound iteration of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, the collision isnâ€™t a matter of interplanetary strife. â€œThunderboltsâ€ has been touted as the unlikely meeting of two of the dominant forces in 21st century American movies: Marvel and A24. This isnâ€™t a co-production, but much of the creative team and many of the stars have ties to the indie studio. â€œThunderboltsâ€ is directed by Jake Schreier, who has directed many episodes of the A24 series â€œBeef,â€ and was written by Joanna Calo (also a â€œBeefâ€ veteran) and Eric Pearson (a Marvel veteran). The connections go further: cinematographer Andrew Droz Palermo (â€œA Ghost Story,â€ â€œThe Green Knightâ€), editor Harry Yoon (â€œMinariâ€) and a score by the band Son Lux (â€œEverything Everywhere All At Onceâ€). Some trailers for â€œThunderboltsâ€ have highlighted these connections, perhaps in hopes of a little A24 auteur cool rubbing off on Hollywoodâ€™s superhero factory. Itâ€™s also a sign of how rough things have gotten for Marvel that, after a string of misfires, itâ€™s leaning on the studio behind â€œSwiss Army Manâ€ for its latest would-be blockbuster. Does that make â€œThunderboltsâ€ a hipper superhero movie? Can you expect â€œBabygirlâ€-like scenes of Black Widow drinking a glass of milk? The answer, of course, is that â€œThunderboltsâ€ has no more indie cred than â€œAvatar.â€ What it is, though, is the best Marvel movie in years. â€œThunderbolts,â€ about a group of MCU rejects who band together after CIA director Valentina Allegra de Fontaine ( Julia Louis-Dreyfus ) tries to erase them and their covert program, is both a return to form for Marvel and something a little different. While thereâ€™s plenty of franchise building going on, â€œThunderboltsâ€ â€” the title of which bears an asterisk â€” is pleasantly stand-alone, and its spurts of spectacle more deftly proceed out of an tenderly told story. If thereâ€™s an influence on â€œThunderbolts,â€ itâ€™s less A24 than James Gunn. It borrows a little of the misfit irreverence of â€œGuardians of the Galaxyâ€ and â€œThe Suicide Squad.â€ But Schreierâ€™s film is leaner and less antic than those movies, and it serves as an IMAX-sized platform for the increasingly obvious movie-star talents of Florence Pugh. In the opening moments of â€œThunderbolts,â€ Pughâ€™s Yelena Belova, a veteran of the Soviet assassin Black Widow program, melancholily stands atop a skyscraper. â€œThereâ€™s something wrong with me,â€ she says. â€œAn emptiness.â€ She drops, a parachute opens, and her narration continues. â€œOr maybe Iâ€™m just bored.â€ Itâ€™s a telling opening for a film that wrestles sometimes earnestly, sometimes a little glibly, with malaise and depression. Yelena is searching for meaning in her life, dragged down by guilt and shame from her past, a pain that even her relentlessly chipper father Alexei, the self-proclaimed Red Guardian (David Harbour, magnificent), canâ€™t quell. When Yelena, on a mission, brutalizes a hallway full of armed guards â€” a shot that, as I critic, am contractually obligated to note is styled after the famous one from Park Chan-wookâ€™s â€œOldboyâ€ â€” Schreier films it from overhead in a shadowy ballet. Shadows and death drape â€œThunderbolts.â€ When Yelena is dispatched on what she says will be her last job, sheâ€™s surprised to encounter others like her â€” include the disgraced John Walker (Wyatt Russell) and the fight-mimicking Taskmaster (Olga Kurylenko) â€” sent to the same location. After some initial tussling, they realize they â€” like the protagonists of â€œToy Story 3â€ â€” are standing inside of an incinerator. Adding to the confusion of their predicament is a guy with no apparent powers who simply introduces himself as â€œBobâ€ (Lewis Pullman, bringing a sensitivity rarely found in these movies). They arenâ€™t quite a bizarro Avengers, but they â€” including Sebastian Stanâ€™s Bucky Barnes, who joins later â€” are all the products of dubious government programs that instill less patriotism than their more plainly heroic counterparts. As a group, theyâ€™re plagued by doubt and uncertainty, and theyâ€™re more inclined to bicker than give rousing speeches. And whenever anyone brushes too closely with Bob, they drift back into the darkest chapters of their own pasts that pull them like a deadweight toward suicidal thoughts. Who, exactly, Bob turns out to be furthers this theme in â€œThunderbolts,â€ which never feels like itâ€™s lurching from one action set piece to another. That the final act of the movie is essentially set in a headspace, rather than above a threatened metropolis, is a testament to the interiority (not a word that often comes up in Marvel movies) of â€œThunderbolts,â€ a film that finds vivid comic-book imagery to render authentic real-life emotions. Thatâ€™s always been the promise of a good comic book, but itâ€™s fair to say that the Marvel movies have recently found that tone elusive. When Louis-Dreyfus, looking just as home in Washington, D.C., as she was in â€œVeep,â€ as De Fontaine declares, â€œThe Avengers are not walking through that door,â€ itâ€™s an acknowledgment â€” like then-Celtics coach Rick Pitino once vowed of Larry Bird â€” that â€œThunderboltsâ€ is here to make the most of what itâ€™s got. Of course, that there are, in fact, more â€œAvengersâ€ films on the way slightly diminishes the sentiment. But they wonâ€™t be missed in â€œThunderbolts.â€ All the assembled parts here, including an especially high-quality cast (even Wendell Pierce!) work together seamlessly in a way that Marvel hasnâ€™t in some time. Most of all, Pugh commands every bit of the movie. Itâ€™s less a revelation than a big-budget confirmation of the screen power of an actor who also has gone from A24 (â€œMidsommarâ€) to Marvel stardom with ease. â€œThunderbolts,â€ a Walt Disney Co. release, is rated PG-13 by the Motion Picture Association for strong violence, language, thematic elements, and some suggestive and drug references. Running time: 126 minutes. Three stars out of four.

headline: Meet David Corenswet, cinemaâ€™s new Superman
article_title: Meet David Corenswet, cinemaâ€™s new Superman
article_content: In true Clark Kent form, the new Superman would like to correct the record. David Corenswet gave an interview to Entertainment Weekly in 2019 where he said his â€œpie in the sky ambitionâ€ was to play Superman. At that point, the role was not on the market. And Corenswet, a Julliard graduate and Philadelphia native, was just making a name for himself in the industry, with plum breakout roles in two Ryan Murphy Netflix series: â€œThe Politicianâ€ and â€œHollywood.â€ Tall, dark, and you know, handsome, people had told him that he looked like Superman for a long time. He did not, he told The Associated Press in a recent interview, think that he was going to get the chance to play him. But a few years later he was actually cast to lead James Gunnâ€™s â€œSupermanâ€ which will begin a new, hopefully high-flying, era for the DC universe of films when it hits theaters on July 11. And that once innocent quote took on a life of its own. Many headlines and stories misinterpreted the phrase and wrote that he said it was his dream role, as though heâ€™d manifested it into existence. â€œI said it was my pie in the sky ambition, which I meant to mean that there was no (expletive) way it was ever going to happen,â€ Corenswet, 31, said. â€œI sort of was thinking of it as, â€˜Oh, who wouldnâ€™t love to get to play an iconic role like that? Wouldnâ€™t it be amazing and impossible if we lived in a universe where that could even be considered?â€™â€ Right around the time when Gunn was starting to think about casting his new Superman movie, he decided to watch his friend Ti Westâ€™s movie â€œPearl.â€ In that darkly comedic horror, Corenswet stood out to him as an interesting and charismatic presence. He played a projectionist at a local movie theater who catches Pearlâ€™s attention (and, later, faces her wrath). West had nice things to say about him too. â€œDavid was one of the very first auditions that I got,â€ Gunn said. â€œInstantly, it was a relief because he had a playful charm about him that was not evident in â€˜Pearl.â€™ He had a sense of humor. That made me go, â€˜Ooh, this might be a really good match.â€™â€ That was just the beginning of the long casting process. Even Nicholas Hoult, who was ultimately cast as Lex Luthor, was up for the part. And though it was â€œextensive,â€ Corenswet said it was one of the most â€œsatisfying audition processesâ€ heâ€™s ever gone through â€” not because he booked the role, but because he felt he got the opportunity to show them what he had to offer. Gunn laughed that Corenswet actually has a lot of Superman in him. â€œSuperman is a square and David is a square,â€ Gunn said. â€œHe listens to American Songbook. Like Dean Martin and Cole Porter. Thatâ€™s what he listens to on his iPad. Thatâ€™s weird. But oh, so Superman.â€ When Gunn called him with the good news, the first person he told was his wife. The second was his sister, who couldnâ€™t pick up the phone because she was on a golf course. â€œShe texted, â€˜Is it possible that was a phone call with super good news?â€™â€ he said. â€œI said, â€˜Yes. Super good news.â€™â€ It may be something of a Superman tradition to try on your predecessorâ€™s costume during a screen test. Henry Cavill did it with Christopher Reeveâ€™s, and Corenswet did it with Cavillâ€™s, which he called a â€œmarvel of engineering.â€ But the first time Corenswet put on his own Superman costume was not some magical, transportive moment. In fact, he said, it was â€œwonderfully mundane.â€ The suit was still in its beginning stages, not totally put together and even a little small, as heâ€™d already started putting on weight for the role. â€œI remember the feeling of kind of growing into the suit and the suit growing around me fitting by fitting,â€ Corenswet said. â€œWe had such an amazing costume team and they built the suit around me over the course of many weeks and months and it started to feel just a little bit like home for me.â€ The first time he felt the impact of it was through the eyes of other people. To him, it was old hat, but when he walked onto set the first time in the suit he noticed something different from the cast and crew. â€œI saw their faces sort of light up and I went, â€˜Wait a minute, these people arenâ€™t that fond of me,â€™â€ he laughed. â€œThatâ€™s when it hits you.â€ Gunn, Rachel Brosnahan, Nicholas Hoult, and Corenswet at CinemaCon in April. (AP Photo/Chris Pizzello) There are almost three roles involved in playing Superman. Thereâ€™s the person he is with his parents and the people he grew up with. Thereâ€™s Clark Kent of the Daily Planet. And then thereâ€™s Superman. â€œHeâ€™s a public facing character, heâ€™s a symbol,â€ Corenswet said. â€œThereâ€™s a presentational element to it, because he does want to present an image of calm and authority. While he doesnâ€™t always feel that way, he always wants to make other people feel that way as Superman.â€ To prepare for Clark Kent, Corenswet looked at the All-Star Superman comic and how Christopher Reeve changed his posture when Lois left the room, but he also drew inspiration for the voice and demeanor way outside of the canon: His brother-in-law, who is 6â€™8â€ and 270 pounds, but is the â€œquietest, most wonderful man.â€ â€œThatâ€™s where I sort of took the spirit of Clark,â€ Corenswet said. â€œHeâ€™s this big presence, but heâ€™s desperately trying to be as small as possible and as quiet as possible.â€ Gunn has promised that the film is â€œa personal journey for Superman thatâ€™s entirely new.â€ Heâ€™s a character who is â€œpretty damn good, but flawed.â€ And anyone who has seen the trailer knows there will be romance with Rachel Brosnahanâ€™s Lois Lane â€” but thereâ€™s even a different spin on that. â€œHeâ€™s in love with her,â€ Gunn said. â€œSheâ€™s the one that needs the convincing in the relationship. Itâ€™s not him. You really see where he needs her in his life.â€ Corenswet said that in addition to the action and thrills, the movie also has a Preston Sturges quality to it with â€œlonging romance and witty comedy.â€ Fitting for their reporter characters, â€œHis Girl Fridayâ€ was also a big reference with â€œthe rhythm, the patter and the feeling of two people in love who really are an equal match for the other.â€ (AP Photo/Tony Avelar) The movie is the start of a new era for DC films, and will raise Corenswetâ€™s profile immeasurably. Heâ€™s been in big movies before, including â€œTwisters.â€ But being Superman is different. â€œThe thing that it changed about my life immediately was that I had this amazing mission that I got to go on of playing the part and getting to be a piece of making this awesome film,â€ he said. â€œI have so many new friends now. James brings together such a familial cast and crew. And shooting the film is sort of like an extended summer camp.â€ Adding to the summer camp vibes: On the last day they even gathered to watch a little blooper reel that Gunn had put together. But what will happen come release is not really something he can fathom at this point. â€œI expect some things will change when the film comes out,â€ he said. â€œBut you know, one still has to wake up and eat breakfast.â€ ___ For more on this yearâ€™s summer movie season, visit: https://apnews.com/hub/movies

headline: Movie Review: â€˜Rustâ€™ is a serviceable Western, haunted throughout by its tragic offscreen history
article_title: Movie Review: â€˜Rustâ€™ is a serviceable Western, haunted throughout by its tragic offscreen history
article_content: Surely, bringing an audience to tears with a poignant ending is something every filmmaker dreams of. And yet the moment that inspires a genuine, unambiguous tear in â€œRustâ€ is born of a true nightmare. â€œ...for Halyna,â€ the screen reads as the film comes to a close. Halyna Hutchinsâ€™ name also appears in Ukrainian. And weâ€™re given a favored quote from the late cinematographer: â€œWhat can we do to make this better?â€ Just as thereâ€™s no way to make this filmâ€™s offscreen history any better, thereâ€™s no way to write a normal review of a movie that is anything but. â€œRustâ€ has inevitably and inexorably become synonymous with tragedy: Hutchinsâ€™ shocking death during an on-set rehearsal, when producer-star Alec Baldwin pointed a pistol at her that somehow contained a live round. It discharged, killing her and wounding director Joel Souza. An involuntary manslaughter charge against Baldwin was dismissed. The movieâ€™s weapons supervisor is serving an 18-month prison sentence. And eventually, the film was finished, with Souza returning and cinematographer Bianca Cline replacing Hutchins. Souza said at the filmâ€™s premiere in Poland that the family wanted Hutchinsâ€™ work to be seen. The movieâ€™s terse publicity materials note that the original producers will not gain financially from it, and that although terms of a settlement were sealed, â€œit has been confirmed that (husband Matthew) Hutchins and son Andros will receive profits from the film.â€ In any case, the movie is here. It is not, as many surely expect, a uniformly shoddy effort. The plot is basic and the dialogue merely serviceable, but there are lovely scenery shots throughout, the vastness, gentle light and deep colors of the American West illustrated carefully and evocatively by Hutchinsâ€™ â€” and Clineâ€™s â€” camera work. Yes, the cinematography is what stands out here. There are also several compelling performances, though Baldwinâ€™s somewhat halting, somber turn is not among them. Most of all, though, thereâ€™s not a moment in â€œRustâ€ in which one loses awareness of the tragedy. While the scene weâ€™ve all read about does not appear, there is constant gunfire, this being a Western. Itâ€™s hard to forget about a shooting while watching so much shooting. In fact, we begin with an accidental shooting. The unfortunate perpetrator is Lucas Hollister, a teenager in 1880s Wyoming whoâ€™s recently been orphaned, along with his little brother. We learn later that their father shot himself a year after their mother died. So Lucas (Patrick Scott McDermott, in an accomplished performance) has become the parent. On a trip into town, Lucas gets into a scuffle with another boy whoâ€™s insulting their late mother, hurting him. The rancher father demands that Lucas come work for him to pay off his debt. And when he comes to the desolate farm where the boys live to get him, Lucas accidentally shoots and kills him, while aiming at a wolf. A judge decides the crime was premeditated and sentences the boy to the gallows. His little brother comes each night to the prison to sleep next to him. Things look bleak â€” until a shadowy character with a white beard comes to break him out of the jailhouse, killing whoever gets in the way. â€œYou tell any SOB who comes after me that he will shake hands with the devil himself,â€ says the mystery man. Itâ€™s Harlan Rust (Baldwin), a notorious outlaw who hasnâ€™t been seen for years. He is also Lucasâ€™ estranged grandfather, having been alerted to the boyâ€™s plight by his sister (Frances Fisher, excellent). Thus begins the great chase. Rust and Lucas flee towards Mexico, the only place they can be safe. On their tail are a plethora of pursuers: Sheriff Wood Helm (Josh Hopkins) and various bounty hunters, chief among them the brutal Fenton â€œPreacherâ€ Lang (Travis Fimmel, appropriately fearsome). The two donâ€™t get along at first â€” they never do, in such stories â€” and Lucas aches to get back to his brother. But Rust convinces him itâ€™s better to stay alive. Eventually, luck runs out for the pair, and someone will have to pay. But for its unique circumstances, one can imagine â€œRustâ€ coming and going without much of a ripple. The question now is, who is going to be seeing this movie? Certainly many people will come â€” or watch at home â€” out of morbid curiosity. What they will find is a movie better in some aspects â€” especially, and poignantly, the cinematography â€” than they may have suspected. But it is one that will always be defined, and reflected in every frame, by its tragic history. And thereâ€™s no real way to make that better. â€œRust,â€ a Falling Forward release, is unrated by the Motion Picture Association. Running time: 139 minutes. One and half stars out of four.

headline: Movie Review: Thriller â€˜The Surferâ€™ brings Nicolas Cage to a boil
article_title: Movie Review: Thriller â€˜The Surferâ€™ brings Nicolas Cage to a boil
article_content: For a long, sun-addled stretch, Lorcan Finneganâ€™s beach-set â€œThe Surferâ€ simmers as a deliciously punishing nightmare, driving Nicolas Cage into his most natural state: a boil. â€œDonâ€™t live here, donâ€™t surf here,â€ is the slogan at a pristine stretch of beach along Luna Bay on the Australian coast where our unnamed protagonist (Cage) has come to surf with his teenage son (Finn Little). The â€œlocals onlyâ€ signs, though, donâ€™t deter him. He was born there, and has come back to surf the break and show his son the million-dollar house on the hills nearby he plans to buy. But the situation rapidly disintegrates. Heâ€™s roughed up by the pushy local surfers, his son takes off, and one issue after another keeps him stuck there on a hillside overlooking the ocean. Anyone who comes to â€œThe Surferâ€ expecting glamorous photography of perfectly tubular waves will be disappointed. This is a movie that gets a remarkable amount of mileage out of a parking lot. It also belongs to that small niche of films where things get so unbearably terrible for the protagonist that the psychodrama becomes more a matter of endurance than pure entertainment. Iâ€™m thinking of movies like â€œU-turnâ€ or â€œAfflictionâ€ â€” films where a characterâ€™s inability to reckon with their reality spirals miserably. As time wears on, Cageâ€™s character gets bloodied, sunburned and incredibly thirsty, and the film grows hallucinatory and surreal. There are snakes, rats and bird eggs. The Lexus he arrives in is towed. His suit gets dusty and ripped. Small nuisances â€” a dead cellphone battery â€” accumulate. The sun seems to be melting his brain, so much so that heâ€™s no longer sure of who he is, and we start to doubt whatâ€™s real, too. Whatâ€™s happening here? The Surfer, as heâ€™s credited, is hell-bent on reclaiming something. He envisions reuniting with his family at the new house, but his separated wife, on the phone, tells him she wants a divorce. Is â€œThe Surfer,â€ penned by Thomas Martin, a metaphor for knowing when to cut bait? Cageâ€™s character wonâ€™t accept his loses, and so he ultimately comes to risk much more. When Finnegan begins to answer these questions in a third act that brings us closer to the surfer bros on the beach, â€œThe Surferâ€ becomes more tolerable to watch and yet less transfixing. The beach gang, led by a man named Scally (Julian McMahon), are something of a cult for reviving an old-fashioned idea of masculinity. With this turn, the strong undertow of â€œThe Surferâ€ dissipates. But if there was ever an actor to elevate pulpy, not-fully formed genre material, itâ€™s Cage. His performance of a man brought to near-disintegration can be neatly filed alongside Cageâ€™s many other head trips to the brink. All he needs is a bluff above a beach to make â€œThe Surferâ€ churn with the currents of a man tenuously close to being swept out to sea. â€œThe Surfer,â€ a Roadside Attractions release thatâ€™s in theaters Friday, is rated R by the Motion Picture Association for language, suicide, some violence, drug content and sexual material. Running time: 103 minutes. Three stars out of four.

headline: Movie Review: â€˜Aprilâ€™ is shattering and essential
article_title: Movie Review: â€˜Aprilâ€™ is shattering and essential
article_content: Whatever cruelness you might assign to the month, Dea Kulumbegashviliâ€™s â€œAprilâ€ probably has it beat. Kulumbegashviliâ€™s shattering, sensational film is set in a hardscrabble, provincial region of Georgia, the Eastern European country. Nina (Ia Sukhitashvili) is the leading obstetrician at the local hospital and she leads a punishing life. In the filmâ€™s opening scenes, she delivers a baby â€” Kulumbegashvili films it from overhead â€” who doesnâ€™t cry once born. Sterile hallways and men demanding answers follow the stillbirth and the fleshy, bloody images of the operating room. Though Nina has done thousands of deliveries, the father calls for a police investigation. Left alone with Nina, he tells her he knows she gives abortions in the village. He calls her a murderer and spits on her.
